Much. Better.By Bon AppétitFebruary 26, 2018FacebookTwitterEmailPhoto by David AlvaradoFacebookTwitterEmailThe perfection of some sandwiches lies in their simplicity (say, a ham and cheese with nothing but the highest quality ham, cheese, and don’t forget the butter). Others, however, benefit from a little something extra—a secret sauce that’s not necessarily a secret sauce, if you will. They’re the X-factor ingredients or techniques that take a sandwich to the next level, where it goes from being lunch to a true revelation between two pieces of bread. We asked chefs to share the little tricks they rely on that distinguish their dishes from our home versions.A BLT is all about simplicity, but a suped-up mayonnaise won't hurt—recipes here.
Christopher TestaniDoctor Up Your Mayo“We do a special sauce, which is mayo, ketchup, mustard, and chopped dill pickles. That’s pretty much good on everything. We also make Russian dressing, which is mayo-based. And our white sauce is based off of a New York City halal truck, which is mayo and vinegar, so we make one with mayo, sour cream, and white vinegar.” —Kevin Pemoulie, Mean Sandwich, SeattleCut Down on the Bread“When you get a sandwich that’s half bread or more, that’s a real bummer. We’ll slice [our rolls] open and pull a little bit of the bread from the inside as soon as they walk in from the baker. You [want] all the crust, but to keep the focus on what’s inside. It’s laborious on top of the labor we’re paying for to have the bread made, but it’s our number-one rule.” —Megan Sanchez and Alec Morrison, Güero, Portland, ORPut Something Crispy On It“I’m all about crispy bits—fried quinoa, crispy shallots, sugar-fried garlic [sliced garlic tossed in sugar, then fried], and toasted sesame seeds. These things bring a ton of flavor and texture variance to each bite.” —Joseph Frietze, Publican Quality Meats, ChicagoIf you’re headed to Durham soon, get a big sandwich at Lucky’s (and send us pics).
Photo by D.L. AndersonUse Chunky Almond Butter Where You Least Expect It“We make a chunky almond butter and put that on our chicken salad sandwich with bacon. There’s something a little over the top about it, but they go really
well together.” —Drew Brown, Lucky's Deli, Durham, NCTwo Sauces Is Better Than One“If you can use two sauces, it’ll be that much more interesting. Our Italian grinder has an aioli and an oregano vinaigrette. Our cauliflower banh mi has a Thai vinaigrette and a spicy mayo.” —Todd Ginsberg, Fred's Meat & Bread, AtlantaGriddle with Something Extra“We brush guajillo paste onto some of our rolls before griddling. It creates this savory dark red chile bread that gets extra crispy. At home you could use sauce from
a can of chipotles in adobo.” —Megan Sanchez and Alec Morrison, Güero, Portland, ORThe collard green melt from Turkey and the Wolf was so good we had to get the recipe.
Photo by Alex LauFreshen Things Up“If you want to put herbs on your sandwich, put way more than you think you need. Just go huge on herbs.
